<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#bg75401a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A> </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dk75401_item_7._management_s_discussio__ite03668"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dk75401_1"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>  ITEM 7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations should be read in conjunction with, and are
qualified by reference to, our Consolidated Financial Statements and related notes thereto in Item&nbsp;8 of this report and Selected Financial Data included in Item&nbsp;6 of this report. Certain
statements set forth below under this caption constitute "forward-looking statements" within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform of 1995. Refer to the "Cautionary Statement About
Forward Looking Statements" preceding Item&nbsp;1 of this report. Also, for a discussion of certain risk factors applicable to our business and operations see "Risk Factors" in Item&nbsp;1A of
this report. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Overview  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We were founded in 1984, as a cleaner coal technology, energy production and environmental solutions company focused on developing our
proprietary technologies. Our goal now is to leverage an integrated technology strategy, including a coal-based technology platform and proven production process to deliver a cleaner, more
efficient and affordable solid fuel available to meet the growing energy demands of industrial and utility customers while addressing important environmental concerns. In addition, we are leveraging a
science-based carbon information management software solution built on a platform of IBM products and solutions to measure greenhouse gases and certify carbon emission reduction credits. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
November&nbsp;2008, we requested Houlihan Lokey, an international investment bank, to provide independent advice to our management and board of directors as we continue to explore
the strategic positioning of the company. We expect to consider and evaluate several alternatives during the engagement, including, but not limited to, the potential sale or joint venture of our
Buckeye subsidiary. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
March 2008, we suspended operations at our Fort Union plant in order to redirect constrained resources, both capital and human, to focus on the commercialization of this process in
future K-Fuel plants. Suspending production at Fort Union enabled us to reduce our cash expenditures. The significant resources invested in the Fort Union plant served three important
purposes: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>First, as an engineering and process improvement platform, the Fort Union plant allowed Evergreen and Bechtel engineers
and scientists to dramatically improve the performance of the K-Fuel process.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Second, Fort Union served as an important coal testing facility that allowed Evergreen to build a test results database
from more than 100 coal types drawn from across the globe.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Third, Fort Union served as an important business development tool and production platform for thousands of tons of
K-Fuel used for marketing and test burn purposes. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To
date, we have idled the Fort Union boiler, processing towers and other equipment at the site and are safeguarding the assets and maintaining the plant in a non-operational
mode. While we would be able to resume operations at the Fort Union plant to demonstrate the technology or to provide K-Fuel refined coal for test burns at utilities or other industrial
sites, we would be required to return equipment to operational status, which could take several months. As time passes and the plant remains idled, the time and costs to convert it to an operational
status will increase. We continue to evaluate redeploying some of the equipment to a future K-Fuel facility site. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
consolidated financial statements include our accounts and the accounts of our wholly and majority-owned subsidiaries, including the nine months ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 for
Buckeye Industrial Mining&nbsp;Co. (acquisition date of April&nbsp;3, 2006). We consolidate all of our majority-owned subsidiaries and reflect as minority interest the portion of these entities
that we do not own and recorded in other long-term liabilities. Intercompany transactions and balances have been eliminated. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=40,EFW="2191621",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=570751,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK123:[09ZAB1.09ZAB75401]DK75401A.;18',USER='BSKELLE',CD='25-MAR-2009;23:15' -->
<A NAME="page_dk75401_1_41"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg75401a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
segments include the C-Lock segment, Plant segment, Mining segment and Technology segment. The Mining segment primarily represents our mining operations of our subsidiary, Buckeye
Industrial Mining&nbsp;Co., and includes certain marketing personnel, the ash disposal facility and the preparation and blending facility. The C-lock segment reflects activities related
to the measurement of green house gases and certification of environmental improvements as carbon credits. The Plant segment primarily represents revenue and costs related to our Fort Union plant in
Gillette, Wyoming, at which we suspended operations in March 2008. The Technology segment is comprised of all other operations that use, apply, own or otherwise advance our proprietary, patented
K-Fuel process, including our headquarters and related operations, activities of Evergreen Energy Asia Pacific and KFx Technology,&nbsp;LLC, which holds the licenses to our technology.
Corporate costs within our Technology segment are allocated to our other segments, generally on a percentage based on the number of employees, total segment operating expenses, or segment operating
expenses plus segment capital expenditures. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Significant Trends  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For the last several years, our operations have been focused on developing our technology and the construction of the Fort Union plant.
As a result, we have limited revenues from K-Fuel refined coal and, historically most of our costs are related to general and administrative expenses. With the addition of Buckeye, we have
begun to generate revenue and incur more substantial mining costs. In the future, we plan to build, own and operate K-Fuel and K-Direct refineries domestically and
internationally, both
wholly owned and through joint ventures. Through C-Lock Technology we plan to generate future revenues from the measurement of greenhouse gases and certification of environmental
improvements as carbon credits. The following discussion and analysis is focused on the events and trends that we believe have or will in the future have the most significant impact on our business. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Revenue Trends  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the future we expect to generate revenue from the following sources: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>coal sales from our Buckeye operations;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>revenues from the measurement of carbon credits using our web-based patented technology; </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>revenues from production facilities including K-Fuel and K-Direct plants domestically and
internationally; and  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>licensing of our technology, including license fees for constructing a plant and royalty fees for operating a plant. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
have granted certain rights and limited licenses for the use of certain K-Fuel technology, which may limit our revenue from production of K-Fuel refined coal
to the extent that the rights are exercised. See Item&nbsp;8 Note&#151;5 Other Assets and Note&#151;13 Commitments and Contingencies to our Consolidated Financial Statements for
further details. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Expense Trends  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Coal mining operating expenses  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;With the acquisition of Buckeye, we have incurred mine operating expenses including all costs associated with the mining of saleable
coal and costs relating to our coal ash disposal facility. As capital is available, we anticipate increasing our production at our mines. We expect that the revenue generated from increased production
will exceed the incremental mining costs. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Fort Union  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In March 2008, we suspended operations at our Fort Union plant in order to redirect constrained resources, both capital and human, to
focus on the commercialization of this process in future K-Fuel </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=41,EFW="2191621",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=55517,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK123:[09ZAB1.09ZAB75401]DK75401A.;18',USER='BSKELLE',CD='25-MAR-2009;23:15' -->
<A NAME="page_dk75401_1_42"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg75401a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>plants.
Suspending production at Fort Union enabled us to reduce our cash expenditures. Overall, while we anticipate costs to decline in 2009, we will continue to incur various costs related to
maintaining the site in a non-operational mode. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Future K-Fuel and K-Direct facilities  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As we build future K-Fuel and K-Direct facilities and these facilities begin continuous operation, we will
incur additional operational expenses, the most significant being: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>coal transportation costs;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>raw material costs;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>outsourced engineering and technical support;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>plant maintenance costs;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>plant personnel labor costs;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>fluid processing costs;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>by-product and water disposal costs; and  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>royalty costs, relating to fees we owe to parties who own certain rights that support our patents and proprietary
technology, primarily the Koppelman estate. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See
further discussion of the royalty owed to the estate of Edward Koppelman in Note&nbsp;5&#151;Other Assets in Item&nbsp;8 of this report. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> General and administrative expenses  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As we identify business development opportunities, build new plants, and generally expand our business including hiring additional
personnel at our corporate offices, future plants and C-Lock locations and increasing outsourced professional services, we will incur additional expenses, the most significant of which
are: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>payroll and related burdens;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>non-cash, share-based compensation;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>business development costs for potential future K-Fuel and K-Direct plants; </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>rent and utilities; and  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>professional support fees. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
anticipate that accounting for non-cash, share-based compensation will add approximately $6.0&nbsp;million to $9.0&nbsp;million per year in the foreseeable future to
our expenses. In the event we should achieve certain performance goals, we would significantly accelerate recognition of these costs. Costs such as payroll and related burdens, professional support
fees and utilities are variable costs that increase with size and adding locations. As we build new plants and expand our vertical integration strategy, we expect these costs to increase in future
periods. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Results of Operations  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Comparison of Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007  </I></B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Revenue  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenues for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 were $58.9&nbsp;million compared to $48.7&nbsp;million for the same period
ended December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=42,EFW="2191621",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=597208,FOLIO='42',FILE='DISK123:[09ZAB1.09ZAB75401]DK75401A.;18',USER='BSKELLE',CD='25-MAR-2009;23:15' -->
<A NAME="page_dk75401_1_43"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg75401a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenues
in our Mining segment for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 were $58.4&nbsp;million and $47.4&nbsp;million for the same period ended December&nbsp;31, 2007
respectively, as follows: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Coal revenue includes mined raw and prepared coal sales within our Buckeye operations. Buckeye coal sales, including
transportation costs charged to customers, were $50.7&nbsp;million and $39.4&nbsp;million, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007, respectively. Coal sales for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2008 were 727,197 tons at $69.72 sales realization per ton sold compared to 728,059 tons at $54.12 sales realization per tons sold for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007. The
increase in the sales realization per ton sold for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 was due to higher coal prices when compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007. Our production tons
for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, were less than anticipated due to power outages and other weather issues related to Hurricane Ike. In addition, we experienced unexpected adverse roof
conditions resulting from clay vein slip areas in a section of one of our underground mining veins. We have resolved the roof conditions by using longer bolts in each of the main entries, more bolts
and narrowing the belt entry. We were also required to obtain the Mine Safety and Health Administrations approval of the revised roof control and ventilation plans, which took longer than anticipated.
We believe that all issues are resolved and Buckeye is now producing at expected levels. We anticipate coal prices to remain consistent with the 2008 prices in 2009.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Brokered coal sales, net include the revenues reduced by costs associated with the purchase of coal from other coal
producers, which we ship directly to customers. We recognized $437,000 of net revenue for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 compared to $514,000 of net revenue for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2007. We enter into brokered coal sales as opportunities arise or as needed to meet certain customers requests, and as a result, revenues in this area fluctuate. </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Ash disposal revenues primarily include revenues generated from the disposal of coal combustion bi-products at
our ash pit in Ohio. Ash disposal revenues were $7.3&nbsp;million and $7.4&nbsp;million for years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007, respectively. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;K-Fuel
refined coal revenue is comprised of sales of our K-Fuel product to third parties. Blended K-Fuel refined coal revenue represents the
proportionate revenue related to K-Fuel that has been blended with other raw or prepared coal from our Buckeye operations and sold to third parties. The remaining revenue related to the
raw or prepared coal is reflected in Mining revenues. K-Fuel refined coal and blended K-Fuel refined coal sales were $463,000 and $1.1&nbsp;million for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007, respectively and are included in our Plant segment. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Coal Mining Operating Expenses  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our coal mining operating expenses include all costs associated with the mining of saleable coal and costs relating to our coal ash
disposal facility at Buckeye, which principally comprises our Mining segment. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Coal mining operating expenses  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Coal mining operating expenses include employee-related costs, outside contracted mining costs for our underground mines, internal and
external coal transportation costs, blasting, drilling, heavy equipment costs, purchased coal and other mining-related costs. Coal mining operating expenses were $42.4&nbsp;million and
$38.3&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007, respectively. The increase in cost per ton in comparing the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 to 2007 is primarily due to
the increased price of fuel used to mine and transport coal. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Ash disposal  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ash disposal expenses include employee-related costs, consulting costs, costs of repairs and maintaining culverts and drainage ponds,
transportation, and heavy equipment costs and other costs </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=43,EFW="2191621",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=218007,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK123:[09ZAB1.09ZAB75401]DK75401A.;18',USER='BSKELLE',CD='25-MAR-2009;23:15' -->
<A NAME="page_dk75401_1_44"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg75401a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>associated
with the ash disposal facility. Ash disposal expenses were $5.4&nbsp;million and $4.8&nbsp;million for the periods ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007, respectively. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> General and Administrative  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Corporate costs within our Technology segment are allocated to our other segments, generally on a percentage based on the number of
employees, total segment operating
expenses or segment operating expenses plus segment capital expenditures. As a result of idling our Fort Union plant, these allocated costs have significantly decreased in our Plant segment and
increased in other segments most notable in our Technology segment, for the year ended 2008 when compared to 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table summarizes our general and administrative costs for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employee
non-cash, share-based compensation expenses were $6.0&nbsp;million and $19.0&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007,
respectively, substantially all of which related to our Technology segment. The decrease related to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 as compared to 2007, was due to the terminations of two
former executive officers and one-time charges of $10.5&nbsp;million related to the accelerated vesting of a portion of their restricted stock grants. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employee-related
costs were $13.0&nbsp;million and $11.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007, respectively. The increases for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2008 in comparison to the same period in 2007, were primarily due to adding personnel to our C-Lock segment, as well as adding engineering and other personnel in our
Technology segment, recruiting fees, an overall increase in health insurance costs and changes in the allocation of corporate costs to various segments. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
decrease for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 as compared to 2007, was due to less outsourced engineering work as a result of increasing our corporate
engineering staff in our Technology segment. Offsetting these savings were increased professional fees in our C-Lock segment associated with patent-related costs. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Office
and travel costs include airfare, lodging, meals, office rent, marketing, office supplies, phone, publications, subscriptions and utilities. The following table summarizes our
office and travel costs related to each of our segments for years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007. </FONT></P>

both our Technology and C-Lock segments. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Insurance
and other costs primarily include costs related to our property and commercial liability, other insurance and all costs that cannot be categorized elsewhere and include, among
other costs, various business and franchise taxes, licensing fees, repair and maintenance, engineering and technical services and director expenses. The following table summarizes our insurance and
other costs related to each of our segments for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>45</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=45,EFW="2191621",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=741094,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK123:[09ZAB1.09ZAB75401]DK75401A.;18',USER='BSKELLE',CD='25-MAR-2009;23:15' -->
<A NAME="page_dk75401_1_46"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg75401a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Plant costs  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent to the idling of the Fort Union plant, costs primarily consist of salaries and wages, security and repair and maintenance.
Previously, plant costs included purchased raw materials, coal transportation, outsourced engineering and technical support, fluid processing, by-products and water disposal, and
employee-related costs, which are reflected in our Plant segment. Plant costs decreased during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 as compared to 2007, primarily due to the idling of our Fort
Union plant in late March 2008. Overall, while we anticipate costs to decline in 2009, we will continue to incur various costs related to maintaining the site in a non-operating mode. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Depreciation, Depletion and Amortization  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation, depletion and amortization are principally comprised of (1)&nbsp;depletion, based on actual tons mined at our mine
sites in Ohio; (2)&nbsp;amortization related to our patents; and (3)&nbsp;depreciation on other fixed assets using the straight-line method. Depreciation, depletion and amortization
expenses were $9.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 compared to $8.4&nbsp;million during the same period ended 2007. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Research and Development  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Research and development costs include costs incurred to advance, test, or otherwise modify our proprietary technology or develop new
technologies and primarily include costs incurred to operate and maintain our laboratory facilities and professional engineering fees related to off-site testing of our K-Fuel
refined coal. Research and development costs were $79,000 and $876,000 for the years ended 2008 and 2007, respectively. As a result of cost cutting measures, we decreased the number of employees and
the corresponding salary and wages in our lab at our Gillette site. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Asset Impairment Charges  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Asset impairment charges were $18.6&nbsp;million and $122.7&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007,
respectively. Asset impairment charges for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, relate to further impairment of our boiler island which was classified as assets held for sale. See
Note&#151;6 Assets Held for Sale in Item&nbsp;8 of this report for further details. Impairment charges for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 are as follows: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>we suspended operations at our Fort Union plant to allow us to focus on future K-Fuel or K-Direct
plants by redirecting constrained resources, both capital and human, to focus on the commercialization of our process. We incurred impairment charges in our Plant segment totaling
$109.5&nbsp;million.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>pursuant to the guidance of Statements of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;144 "Accounting for the Impairment or
Disposal of Long-Lived Assets", or SFAS&nbsp;144, we are required to evaluate the fair value of our boiler, which is classified as held for sale. As result, of this fair value
calculation we impaired the carrying value of our boiler by $7.8&nbsp;million in our Technology segment;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>we impaired $3.6&nbsp;million of capitalized costs related to projects that we abandoned and/or replaced with more cost
effective projects in our Plant segment; and  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>we impaired capital costs of $2.1&nbsp;million related to a previously announced future potential project with a major
utility because it was determined not to be economically feasible in our Technology segment. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>46</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg75401a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<UL>
<UL>
</UL>
</UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Other Income Expense  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Interest income  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest income was $1.3&nbsp;million and $4.3&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007, respectively.
The decrease in interest income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 was principally attributable to a lower cash balance as well as reduced interest rates during 2008. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Interest expense  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and December&nbsp;31, 2007 was $6.1&nbsp;million and
$3.4&nbsp;million, respectively. Interest expense relates to the $95.0&nbsp;million in aggregate principal amount of our 8.00% convertible secured notes due 2012, which we completed in July 2007.
The increase in interest expense is in direct relation to the time and amount of the notes outstanding in 2008 compared to 2007. We anticipate interest expense to significantly decrease in future
periods due to the conversion of 71% of these outstanding convertible secured notes. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Gain on debt for equity exchange transactions  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, we entered into multiple individually negotiated agreements with certain existing
noteholders to exchange $67.1&nbsp;million in aggregate principal amount of the 8.00% convertible secured notes due 2012, for an aggregate of 48.6&nbsp;million shares of our common stock. We
recognized a $6.1&nbsp;million gain, which was reduced by transaction costs, non-cash reversal of debt issue costs and non-cash adjustment related to the embedded
derivatives. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Other income (expense)  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, other expense was $300,000 as compared to $1.4&nbsp;million of other expense for the
same period ended 2007. Pursuant to FAS&nbsp;133, we estimated the fair value of the embedded derivatives as of July&nbsp;30, 2007, when the notes were issued, and recorded those values as either
assets or liabilities. In addition, we are required to evaluate the fair value of the embedded derivatives at the end of each subsequent reporting period. We recognized a decrease in the fair value of
the derivatives of $934,000 for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008. This fair value adjustment is a non-cash item and each quarter's estimation exercise is impacted, in part, by our
stock price. For additional information, see Note&nbsp;9&#151;Debt included in Item&nbsp;8 of this report. In addition we recognized a $744,000 gain for insurance reimbursements for cost
incurred to repair certain equipment at our Fort Union plant for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Comparison of Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006  </I></B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Revenue  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenues for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 were $48.7&nbsp;million compared to $36.7&nbsp;million for the same period
ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. The increase in revenue primarily relates to our April 2006 acquisition of Buckeye. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, we owned Buckeye for only nine
months. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, we owned Buckeye for the entire twelve-month period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenues
in our Mining segment for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 were $47.4&nbsp;million and $35.9&nbsp;million for the same period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006
respectively, as follows: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Buckeye coal sales, including transportation costs charged to customers, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 were
$39.4&nbsp;million or 728,059 tons at $54.12 sales realization per ton sold and $30.4&nbsp;million or 539,773 tons at $56.32 sales realization per ton sold for the period ended December&nbsp;31,
2006. The decrease in the sales realization per ton sold for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 was due to a mix of types of coals sold during 2007 and downward pressure on coal pricing,
particularly during the first quarter of 2007 resulting from depressed </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>47</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=47,EFW="2191621",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=56497,FOLIO='47',FILE='DISK123:[09ZAB1.09ZAB75401]DK75401B.;11',USER='BSKELLE',CD='25-MAR-2009;23:15' -->
<A NAME="page_dk75401_1_48"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg75401a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>international
coal prices. During periods of depressed coal pricing, we strategically adjust the mix of coal we produce to focus less on our premium coals. As prices had improved in 2008, we increased
production of our premium coals and our sales realization per ton increased in 2008, as compared to 2007.  </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>We recognized $514,000 of net revenue for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 compared to $695,000 of net revenue for
the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. We enter into brokered coal sales as opportunities arise or as needed to meet certain customers requests, and as a result, revenues in this area fluctuate. </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Ash disposal revenues were $7.4&nbsp;million and $4.7&nbsp;million for years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006,
respectively. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;K-Fuel
refined coal and blended K-Fuel refined coal sales were $1.1&nbsp;million and $420,000 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006,
respectively and are included in our Plant segment. K-Fuel refined coal sales were less than expected primarily due to less production at our Fort Union plant for both periods. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Coal Mining Operating Expenses  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Coal mining operating expenses  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Coal mining operating expenses were $38.3&nbsp;million and $28.9&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and
2006, respectively. The increase can be attributed to the acquisition of Buckeye in April 2006, resulting in recording nine months of Buckeye's operation for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006
compared to recording twelve months of Buckeye's operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Ash disposal  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ash disposal expenses were $4.8&nbsp;million and $3.4&nbsp;million for the periods ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006,
respectively. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> General and Administrative  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employee
non-cash, share-based compensation expenses were $19.0&nbsp;million and $9.8&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively,
substantially all of which related to our Technology segment. The increase related to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 as compared to 2006, was due to the terminations of two former executive
officers and one-time charges of $10.5&nbsp;million related to the accelerated vesting of a portion of their restricted stock grants. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>48</FONT></P>

<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=0>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:10pt;text-indent:-10pt;"><FONT SIZE=2> </FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Total Employee-related</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT"  style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>11,721</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>8,045</FONT></TD>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increases for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 in comparison to the comparable period in 2006 were primarily due to a company-wide increase in health insurance
costs and adding personnel, including plant and engineering personnel. In addition, through the acquisition of Buckeye, we incurred twelve months of expense in 2007 compared to nine months of expense
in 2006. The small increase in the technology segment and the substantial increase in the plant segment were due to more corporate resources being used at our Fort Union plant during 2007 and the
associated allocation of those expenses. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
anticipation of hiring additional employees at our corporate office led to our office expansion and relocation in May 2007, and the related increases in rent, utilities and
relocation costs for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 compared to the same period ended 2006. Our travel for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 increased due to an increase in the number
of trips to our Fort Union plant as well as increased business development efforts. In addition, during the same period we incurred </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>49</FONT></P>

<TD style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:10pt;text-indent:-10pt;"><FONT SIZE=2> </FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Total Insurance and other</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT"  style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>4,645</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT"  style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>2,634</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size:1.5pt;" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=2 style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 compared to the same period ended 2006 can be attributed to the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>A licensing fee paid to the owner of the proprietary technology for the measurement of carbon emissions related to the
formation of our subsidiary, C-Lock Technology, Inc, which is reflected in the C-Lock segment;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Increase in insurance due to the acquisition of Buckeye, which is reflected in the Mining segment; </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Increase in business development costs associated with the identification of key public utility leads, which are
candidates for our process, and development of those leads, which is reflected in the Technology segment; and  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Overall increase in property and commercial liability premiums for our Fort Union plant, which is reflected in the Plant
segment. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Plant costs  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Plant costs were higher than anticipated due to general start-up issues with this
first-of-a-kind plant and technical and operation improvements being implemented. Plant costs were $34.7&nbsp;million and $26.3&nbsp;million for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively. During the majority of the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, we were in the construction and commissioning phases and most of the costs incurred
during these phases were capitalized. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, we were in the start-up phase and a higher percentage of costs associated with the operations of our
Fort Union plant were expensed as incurred. In addition, non-capitalized costs increased as a result of engineering and technical work performed to improve and reconfigure our Fort Union
plant. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Depreciation, Depletion and Amortization  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation, depletion and amortization are comprised of (1)&nbsp;depreciation on our Fort Union plant using the
units-of-production method, based on actual tons processed and depreciation on other fixed assets using the straight-line method; (2)&nbsp;depletion, based on
actual tons mined at our mine sites in Ohio; and (3)&nbsp;amortization related to our patents. Depreciation, depletion and amortization expenses were $8.4&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2007 compared to $5.5&nbsp;million during the same period ended 2006. The increases are primarily attributable to the acquisition of Buckeye and the related depreciation and
depletion on our mine sites and property and equipment for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>50</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=11,SEQ=50,EFW="2191621",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=386634,FOLIO='50',FILE='DISK123:[09ZAB1.09ZAB75401]DK75401B.;11',USER='BSKELLE',CD='25-MAR-2009;23:15' -->
<A NAME="page_dk75401_1_51"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg75401a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Research and Development  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Research and development costs were $876,000 and $1.4&nbsp;million for the years ended 2007 and 2006, respectively. The decrease is
primarily a result of our Fort Union plant
entering the start-up phase of operation, which resulted in costs that were previously classified as research and development now being classified as plant costs. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Asset Impairment Charges  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Asset impairment charges were $122.7&nbsp;million for December&nbsp;31, 2007 and were previously described. Asset impairment
charges were $335,000 for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Other Income Expense  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Interest income  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest income was $4.3&nbsp;million and $5.6&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively.
The decrease for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 is attributed to interest earned on our cash balance, which was significantly lower compared to the same period in 2006. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Interest expense  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and December&nbsp;31, 2006 was $3.4&nbsp;million and $6,000,
respectively. The interest expense relates to our long-term debt due 2012, which we completed in July 2007. We pay interest semi-annually at a rate of 8.00% per annum, due on
February&nbsp;1 and August&nbsp;1 of each year, beginning on February&nbsp;1, 2008. For additional information, see Note&nbsp;9&#151;Debt included in Item&nbsp;8 of this report. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Other income (expense)  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, other expense was $1.4&nbsp;million as compared to $1.1&nbsp;million of other
income for the same period ended 2006. We recognized a decrease in the fair value of the derivatives of $1.7&nbsp;million. This fair value adjustment is a non-cash item and each
quarter's estimation exercise is impacted, in part, by our stock price. For additional information, see Note&nbsp;9&#151;Debt included in Item&nbsp;8 of this report. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
November&nbsp;26, 2003, we completed an equity exchange transaction with Rio Tinto Energy America Services Company ("RTEA"), formerly Kennecott Energy Company. As a part of the
exchange transaction, an intercompany working capital loan from Evergreen Energy to Pegasus Technologies&nbsp;Inc. with an outstanding balance of $9.4&nbsp;million was exchanged for a contingent
earn-out agreement of up to $9.4&nbsp;million in the aggregate, plus accrued interest (prime rate plus 500 basis points), payable out of a portion of future cash flows generated by
Pegasus. Due to the contingent nature of this potential stream of future cash flows, we did not recognize an asset or any associated income at the time of the exchange transaction. On May&nbsp;16,
2006, RTEA entered into a transaction involving its investment in Pegasus. Pursuant to the terms of the agreement entered into between us and RTEA dated November&nbsp;7, 2003, which triggered the
earn-out provision, we received a payment of $1.1&nbsp;million during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 from Pegasus as a payment in full satisfaction of the $9.4&nbsp;million
contingent obligation. This transaction had no effect on our note receivable from Pegasus. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> 2009 Liquidity and Capital Resources Discussion  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2008, we have reduced our cash flow used in operations by $15.3&nbsp;million, when compared to 2007. We accomplished these
savings principally by suspending operations at our Fort Union plant, reducing professional fees and other general and administrative costs. These cost reductions were offset by the expansion of our
C-Lock operations, including the addition of personnel and other administrative costs associated with developing a business. In addition, we have invested $16.8&nbsp;million in capital
expenditures, primarily related to Buckeye, C-Lock's software development and completion of </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>51</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=12,SEQ=51,EFW="2191621",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=13773,FOLIO='51',FILE='DISK123:[09ZAB1.09ZAB75401]DK75401B.;11',USER='BSKELLE',CD='25-MAR-2009;23:15' -->
<A NAME="page_dk75401_1_52"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg75401a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>the
K-Fuel enhanced tower design and other K-Fuel process development. The capital expenditures related to Buckeye were related to capitalizable maintenance and acquisition of
certain equipment, which has positioned it to expand its production in 2009 and thereafter. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
previously mentioned, we are evaluating several strategic alternatives including, but not limited to, the potential sale or joint venture of Buckeye. If this evaluation indicates that
sale or joint venture of Buckeye is not appropriate at this time, we will retain and continue to operate it. Alternatively, sale or joint venture of Buckeye could provide Evergreen with immediate
access to significant capital that could be reinvested in the growth of our C-Lock and K-Fuel energy technologies. In order to ensure that we had sufficient operating capital,
we entered into the financing arrangement described below to provide financial flexibility as we complete this evaluation. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
March&nbsp;20, 2009, we executed a senior secured convertible note agreement which provides for the issuance of $15&nbsp;million in aggregate principal amount of 10% Senior
Secured Promissory Notes (the "Notes") in three $5&nbsp;million tranches. The first $5&nbsp;million tranche was funded on March&nbsp;20, 2009. The second $5&nbsp;million tranche, which must be
drawn, will be funded upon our request no later than April&nbsp;3, 2009 and upon satisfaction that all conditions precedent to closing have been met. The third tranche is available to be drawn at
any time prior to the maturity of the Notes upon our request and upon satisfaction that all conditions precedent to closing have been met. The Notes bear interest at a rate of 10% per annum beginning
on the funding date of each tranche through December&nbsp;20, 2009, and all interest is required to be prepaid at the time the Note is issued and is non-refundable. The Notes are secured
by all of Buckeye's assets and Evergreen Operation&nbsp;LLC's equity interest in Buckeye. The Notes will mature at the earlier of December&nbsp;20, 2009 or the sale of Buckeye and may be prepaid
in whole or in part. Upon repayment, we will pay the face amount of the Notes outstanding at the rate of: 105% if repaid by June&nbsp;20, 2009; 110% if repaid after June&nbsp;20, 2009 but before
September&nbsp;20, 2009 and 115% thereafter. The holder of the Notes may, at its option and at any time prior to the maturity date, convert such Notes, in whole or in part, into our common stock at
a conversion price of $3.65 per share. In addition to other covenants, the note purchase agreement places limits on the ability of Buckeye to incur additional indebtedness or incur other liens upon
its property. Please see a detailed description of the Notes in Item&nbsp;9B&#151;Other Information or Note&nbsp;9&#151;Debt in Item&nbsp;8 of this report. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
July 2007, we completed a convertible debt offering that provided us with approximately $72&nbsp;million, net of amounts held in escrow and offering costs. During the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2008, we entered into multiple individually negotiated agreements with certain existing noteholders to exchange $67.1&nbsp;million in aggregate principal amount of the 8.00%
convertible secured notes due 2012, for an aggregate of 48.6&nbsp;million shares of our common stock. We issued all the shares by December 2008 except for 9.3&nbsp;million, which represents
$12.5&nbsp;million of principal value of the notes. During the first quarter of 2009, we closed additional portions of this remaining transaction and issued an aggregate of 4.0&nbsp;million
shares, representing $5.4&nbsp;million of principal value of notes. We anticipate the remaining conversion to take place in 2009. These exchange transactions will dramatically reduce the interest we
owe related to these notes in 2009. Further, we received the requisite consents to amend the indenture and, in compliance with the terms and provisions of the indenture, we, each of the guarantors and
the trustee, executed a supplemental indenture (the "Supplemental Indenture"). See further discussion in Note&nbsp;9- Debt in Item&nbsp;8 of this report. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
believe because of the actions described above, along with the anticipated cash flows from our Buckeye operations, the proceeds of the senior secured convertible note agreement
described above and the ability to adjust capital and certain operational spending, our current cash level is sufficient to support our corporate and other operations for the foreseeable future.
However, if Buckeye experiences unexpected declines in production for any reason, including but not limited to, heavy rains or flooding, slow-downs or suspension of operations for geologic
or any other unanticipated reason, it could adversely impact our cash flow from operations. Further, continued market disruptions associated </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>52</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=13,SEQ=52,EFW="2191621",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=994455,FOLIO='52',FILE='DISK123:[09ZAB1.09ZAB75401]DK75401B.;11',USER='BSKELLE',CD='25-MAR-2009;23:15' -->
<A NAME="page_dk75401_1_53"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg75401a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>with
the global credit crisis could cause broader economic downturns, which may lead to lower demand for our technology or products, increased incidence of customers' inability to pay their accounts,
or insolvency of our customers, any of which could adversely affect our results of operations, liquidity, cash flows, and financial condition. We continue to evaluate our cash position and cash
utilization and may make additional adjustments to capital or certain operating expenditures. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
we complete our strategic evaluation and identify alternatives, or as opportunities arise to construct K-Fuel facilities, further expand Buckeye's production volumes,
accelerate our C-Lock operations, or our anticipated operating cash flows are less than expected, due to among other things, lower than anticipated production at Buckeye or a protracted
global credit crisis, we may need to obtain additional funding. We plan to seek additional capital from time to time as needed principally through: (1)&nbsp;equity offerings; (2)&nbsp;debt or debt
offerings; (3)&nbsp;partnering with third parties in the construction and operation for some of our large-scale commercial plants through the formation of joint ventures; and (4)&nbsp;sales or
potential joint venture of certain assets. While we believe we will obtain additional capital through one or more of the alternatives described, we can provide no assurance that any of the
alternatives will be available to us or be on terms acceptable to us. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Payment Obligations  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table summarizes our future commitments as of December&nbsp;31, 2008: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This
table does not include accounts payable, accrued liabilities, or asset retirement obligations, which are reported in our December&nbsp;31, 2008 Consolidated Balance Sheet. We
generally have not included any obligation in which either party has the right to terminate except as discussed below. Additionally, we have not included royalty payments, as we cannot presently
determine when such payments will be made as such payments are based upon our receipt of cash for licensing and royalties. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
are obligated under non-cancelable operating leases with initial terms exceeding one year relating to office space. Rent expense for the years ended December&nbsp;31,
2008, 2007 and 2006 was $1.1&nbsp;million, $784,000, and $415,000, respectively. Additionally, included in operating leases is the rent obligation associated with our former headquarters totaling
$577,000, which we have sub-leased but are not released from the obligation. Furthermore, included in operating leases is a 47-year port dock lease on the Ohio River, which we
have the right to cancel upon six months written notice. If this lease were cancelled as of December&nbsp;31, 2008, we would be obligated to pay $250,000 rather than the entire obligation of
$23.5&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Purchase
commitments include the purchase of underground mining equipment. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Consulting
and service commitments include an exclusive patent sub-license agreement with the developer of a proprietary technology for the measurement of carbon emissions.
The agreement provides us with an exclusive worldwide sub-license to a technology to standardize the measurement of carbon emissions in energy and agricultural related activities. The
agreement was amended and restated to expand the energy and agricultural activities to all applications of the technology and eliminates other operating requirements. In order to maintain this
licensing arrangement, we are required to make minimum annual royalty payments of $500,000 to the developer of the proprietary technology, with </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>53</FONT></P>

payment extending the arrangement for one year if the parties are in material compliance with the contract. Additionally, consulting and service commitments includes our amended and restated our
umbrella agreement with Bechtel. Through this new program management agreement, we committed to provide Bechtel with $1&nbsp;billion in construction contracts through 2013. Failure to meet this

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Historical View  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Cash Used in Operating Activities  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash used in operating activities was $36.3&nbsp;million, $51.6&nbsp;million, and $30.4&nbsp;million for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2008, 2007 and 2006, respectively. The majority of the cash used in operating activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 relates to cash utilized in our
on-going operations, as adjusted for non-cash items, and changes in operating assets and liabilities. The most significant adjustments to net loss to arrive at cash used in
operating activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 was a $18.6&nbsp;million asset impairment, non-cash, share-based compensation expenses of $6.3&nbsp;million,
depreciation, depletion and amortization of $9.0&nbsp;million and gain on debt for equity exchange transactions of $6.1&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
majority of the cash used in operating activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 relates to cash utilized in our on-going operations, as adjusted for
non-cash items and changes in operating assets and liabilities. The most significant adjustment for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 was a $122.7&nbsp;million impairment charge.
Other significant adjustments to net loss to arrive at cash used in operating activities for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006 were: non-cash compensation expense of
$19.6&nbsp;million and $11.5&nbsp;million in 2007 and 2006, respectively and depreciation, depletion and amortization of $8.4&nbsp;million and $5.5&nbsp;million, respectively, primarily from
the acquisition of Buckeye. </FONT></P>
